Interface TwoPlayerGame

public interface TwoPlayerGame
A game which can be played by two players alternately making moves on a shared playing "board." The board need not be a rectangular plane, but some shared playing surface must exist between the two players.

A TwoPlayerGame is always played in alternate turns where victory may be achieved after either player's move. It is possible to track moves and mandate that both players have the same number of moves before allowing a winner to be declared, but care should be taken that in such cases the gameIsWon() or announceWinner() methods do not prematurely return an incorrect value.

Each player move should be exhaustive of his turn. The TwoPlayerGame is an alternating game (chess for example) as opposed to a sort of "freestyle" game where turn sharing does not occur, as in soccer or a competitive sports. A player's move may have multiple components or inputs, but this must be entirely contained within a single invocation of playerMove() and no reliance may be made upon a reinvocation of this method.
Thus for any instantiation of the TwoPlayerGame, calls to playerOneMove() and playerTwoMove() may be made alternately without concern that one player's turn will not have ended.

    Fields
    Modifier and Type
    Field
    Description
    static int
    NUMBER_OF_PLAYERS
    The number of players playing a two player game.

    Method
    Description

    announceWinner()
    Displays the winner of the game.

    Draws the board to the screen.
    boolean
    gameIsWon()
    Checks to see if one of the players has won.

  • Field Details

    • NUMBER_OF_PLAYERS

      static final int NUMBER_OF_PLAYERS
      The number of players playing a two player game.
      See Also:
      Constant Field Values

  • Method Details

    • drawBoard

      void drawBoard()
      Draws the board to the screen. This could be done using pretty println() statements or JavaFX (wow!).

    • playerOneMove

      void playerOneMove()
      Requests a move from the first player and makes the move.

    • playerTwoMove

      void playerTwoMove()
      Requests a move from the second player and makes the move.

    • gameIsWon

      boolean gameIsWon()
      Checks to see if one of the players has won.
      Returns:
      true if one player has won the game, false otherwise.

    • announceWinner

      void announceWinner()
      Displays the winner of the game. This could be done by printing to the command line or in some other way. This method should only print the winner of the game if the game has been won.
